Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: On-Chip Optical Amplifier Using Novel Erbium-Chloride Silicate Single Crystal Nanowires

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to conduct early stage exploratory research to develop a high-gain on-chip optical amplifier using erbium chloride silicate, a novel material recently synthesized by the PI's group. The main advantage of the new material is the high quality of the single crystals with high erbium density.

The intellectual merits lie in the novelty of materials, the importance of the fundamental understanding of this important class of materials, and the potential impact to on-chip nanophotonic systems. Understanding the fundamental issues such as lifetimes of various states and linewidths of the transitions would impact many future device applications. The transformative aspect of this research is the paradigm shift from doped materials to rare-earth compounds as high gain materials. Optical amplifiers on the scale of 100 nanometers would provide a game-changing solution for on-chip nanophotonic systems, allowing for unprecedentedly large-scale integration of computing and communication functionalities. Such high-risk and high pay-off research is ideally suited for an EAGER project.

The broader impact of the proposed research includes an array of other applications such as quantum information at telecomm wavelengths and on-chip atomic clocks. The enabled photonic capabilities would fundamentally revolutionize and potentially unify electronics-based computing and photonics-based communication, impacting information technology and our society in general. The proposed efforts will also integrate research with education of minority and female students. The results of the research will be rapidly incorporated into undergraduate projects and graduate curriculum, so that education can benefit from the proposed research in a timely fashion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Objective of this EAGER proposal was to conduct early stage exploratory research to develop a high-gain on-chip optical amplifier using erbium chloride silicate (ECS), a novel compound material recently synthesized by PI’s group. The main advantage of the new material is the high quality of the single crystals with high erbium density where Er is part of crystal compound rather than as dopants in typical Erbium materials. The intellectual merits lie in the novelty of materials, the importance of the fundamental understanding of this important class of materials, and the potential impact to on-chip nanophotonic systems. Fundamental understanding of this novel class of rare-earth compounds would impact many future device applications. During the performance period, several important experiments were carried out to understand the basic material properties and to explore the great potential of this novel materials as a nanophotonic amplifier or light source as described in the following:  

1)      The first was to perform the optical absorption measurement of the ECS nanowires over the entire spectrum from 400 nm to 1600 nm. While Erbium ion absorption in this wavelength range is known in doped materials, similar information is not available in a high quality single crystal compound material where erbium is not doped ion, rather part of compound crystal, thus with orders of magnitude higher content. Our material provided a unique opportunity to measure the intrinsic properties of such materials, since similar thin film materials have poor crystal quality and the resulting inhomogeneous broadening masks intrinsic spectral features. One of the challenges for such measurement, however, was the scattering nature of nanomaterials, making standard absorption measurement based on transmission vs. reflection impossible. Our measurement in an integration sphere provided the first such benchmark spectral result and will be extremely useful in determining the spectral features and selection rules of this material. The absorption measurement strategy could be also beneficial to other nanomaterials.

2)      The second experiment was to measure signal enhancement of the intrinsic material. Due to the nano-features related porosity, such a signal enhancement is difficult to measure with an ensemble of nanowires. The measurement along a single nanowire raises several challenges due to in- and out-coupling and the mechanical vibration of a single nanowire. Our careful design eventually led to successful experiments that established the largest signal enhancement of any erbium materials. The same pump-probe strategy will be important for using a single erbium silicate nanowire as a nanophotonic waveguide.

3)      The third important issue was to determine the intrinsic optical gain of erbium chloride silicate. This is the most important issue in the proposed effort to determine the applicability of our material as a nanoscale Si-compatible amplifier.  To this end, we needed to determine the absolute absorption coefficient of our ECS material at 1531 nm wavelength. We adopted two independent methods to this end. The first is a direct pump-probe experiment through a single nanowire. The second method was to measure the green luminescence decay along a single nanowire. The second method turned out to be the most accurate and reliable. The low bound of the optical gain is measured to be 30 dB per centimeter. This net optical gain is the largest of any erbium material ever measured. This also represents the first time that positive optical gain has been measured for an erbium compound material. Typical optical gain in other erbium doped materials is around 1 to 5 dB per centimeter.
